In all honesty, I don't think that they were a superior warrior nation.

 
=

I believe that the warrior ethic of unquestioned loyalty that preferred de=
ath to failure was, however noble sounding, the undoing of the Japanese in =
dealing with the rest of the world.

 

They had long lived grand feudal so=
cieties because of their physical isolation, and brutal swift justice syste=
ms that maintained them. But these enabling factors did not produce a warri=
or class superior to any other.

 

There are many other reasons to study a=
nd admire the Samurai, and the culture that created them. But comparing the=
m as individuals or as a national body, to those of any other nation, will =
only bring you to similarities, not superiorities.
